Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT29-COX 
    

      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR TUESDAY, Aug. 29, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   NATIONAL

   RAMSEY _ ATLANTA _ We'll be where the Ramseys are being
questioned by Boulder, Colo., cops. Not expecting any news _
questioning could go on for two days. If there's little or no news,
we'll plan on writing a media circus piece. (Schneider, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). WITH PHOTO.

   HAZING _ WASHINGTON _ The biggest high school hazing survey ever
is to be released Monday. The survey on the extent, nature and
consequences of ``Initiation Rites in American High Schools'' was
conducted by researchers from Alfred University in New York, who
last year surveyed colleges on hazing nationally after one of
Alfred's students died. (Mollison, Cox News Service). 16.

   WAN: Location Atlanta, category National, subcategory Education.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   MURRAY-COLUMN _ Friend of mine called from England last week to
tell me what a good time he and his wife were having. I have a
theory about people calling from faraway places to tell me what a
good time they're having. The more they call, the more they're
wishing they were back home. (Murray, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio _ Paul Thompson has a pig farm
three miles west of Stuart, Fla. where he, his wife, and the pigs
have lived happily since 1957 _ until recently. In the mid-1990s a
developer bought the neighboring land and built a golf course and
some swanky houses. Now they want the pig farmer to go because the
newcomers are objecting to the smell, and to the country music
Farmer Thompson plays most days to keep his porkers happy. You tell
me _ who was there first? (Schuett, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   LANE-COLUMN _ DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. _ Big deal television events
put a nonviewer in an awkward position. About 51 million people saw
the last episode of ``Survivor.'' Or will admit to it. Enough to
stimulate serious media overkill and dominate conversation in
cafeterias, bars, offices, gyms and student unions everywhere. When
faced with these conversations do you say, ``No, I have no
knowledge of this 'Survivor' thing of which you speak'' and sound
like a snob? A spoilsport affecting the air of an ethical
vegetarian at a weenie roast? (Lane, Daytona Beach News-Journal)
MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   DELTA-NEWPLANE _ Delta takes delivery of its first Boeing
767-400, a stretched version of the popular widebody. This plane
will enble Delta to finally put its L-1011 Tri-Stars (nicknamed
Tritanics by some crewmembers) out to pasture. It will fly
high-volume domestic routes such as Atlanta-Hawaii. It's the third
new model received by Delta under a 1997 deal wit Boeing for
hundreds of new jets. (Fonti, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12.
WITH PHOTO.

   SCANNERS _ You can't click your mouse on this newspaper page and
jump to an Internet site. But media companies around the nation are
experimenting with similar print-to-Web connections. Use a special
scanner to click on a bar code in a magazine or newspaper story or
ad and jump directly to a related Web site on your computer. The
question is, will enough readers and advertisers use it to make it
worthwhile? (Kempner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 28.

   BIZMAGS _ A rundown of the week's financial press. (Walker,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TECHNOLOGY

   COXNET PTECH PAGE

   EDS: This is the CoxNet PTECH page for the current week. This
layout is available now.

   COXNET PTECH0827 _ With half of American workers online,
in-touch and out-performing their predecessors, the technological
revolution promises a Brave New World Wide Web. Increasingly, that
new work world includes some Big Brother oversight. (Chapman,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) With illustration (Cumming, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   WITH

   TECHNOBUDDY column _ Use common sense when evaluating reports on
technology. The experts and reporters don't always get it
right.(Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TECH TOOLS _ A company called IWare makes a product called
uWare. For the most part, it is nothing more than an advertising
carrier

   for a host of e-businesses. (Warner, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   GADGETS _ You may remember a time when you were a kid and you
got a toy compass. Today you can carry around a digital device that
does the same thing more reliably. The Co-Pilot from Precision
Navigation Inc. gives you a digital readout that tells you exactly
which way you're headed with an accuracy of plus or minus 5
degrees. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News) with 1 col. photo of the
Co-Pilot

   GAME CORNER _ A look at Colony Wars III: Red Sun for the
PlayStation, an enjoyable, intergalactic shoot-'em-up. With aurally
and visually pleasing lasers, explosions and spaceships, ``Red
Sun'' is the gaming equivalent of a good summer blockbuster. With 1
col. close-up of cover.TECH-WORKGEAR _ The latest in digital work
gear. This week: Case Logic CD-ROM cases. (Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-HOMEGEAR _ The latest in digital home gear. This week:
ShowOffs Photo Print Sheets. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-KIDGEAR _ Games for children. This week: Gundam Wing
plastic model kits. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   WEEWEB _ Websites for children. This week: www.studyweb.com.
(Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-GAMER _ Games for the console and desktop aimed at the
moderate to advanced gamer. This week: Sega's Seaman. (Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECHNOBUDDY_ Popular column about personal computing written for
the average user. This week: Writeable CD drive. (Husted, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECH-TOOLS _ Software reviews. This week: Reader input on
digital photos. (Warner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   NETWATCH _ What's new on the Web. This week: Department store
shopping online. (Katz, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   MONITOR _ Review of Onimusha: Warlords adventure game for
PlayStation2. (Serra, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-SAVVY _ Question and answer column focusing on using
computers and other technology as tools to get jobs done.
(Cleere/Rudd, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.TECH-FAMILY _
Weekly column focusing on family related computer technology. This
week: Long distance calls via the Web. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   SEGA-GAME-REVIEW _ It's been well over a year since I first saw
screen shots of a promising Dreamcast game titled ``Ecco the
Dolphin.'' It was one of the best-looking games I had ever seen,
and now it's finally here and I couldn't be happier. (Oxford,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   NINTENDO-GAME-REVIEW _ Nintendo fans have something to cheer
about. The company revealed its new video gaming systems Thursday
at the Spaceworld trade show in Tokyo, the Game Boy Advance.
(Oxford, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   X-MEN-REVIEW _ ``X-Men's'' popularity seems to be peaking again
with a recent movie starring America's favorite mutant fighters,
along with a new video game titled ``X-Men: Mutant Academy.'' The
Activision product is a gem for PlayStation owners. The console
system is rapidly losing attention from the industry's top
developers because of the approaching arrival of the PlayStation 2
on Oct. 26. (Carvell, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   LIFESTYLE

   BARNUM-TENT _ Barnum, trying to get on the new Cirque market of
new-fangled acts in an old-fashioned tent, raises next to
Centennial Olympic Park its first tent since 1956 to present its
new show, Kaleidoscape. (Hulbert, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
15.

   CONSUMERQ&A _ AUSTIN, Texas _ Consumer Q&A. (Greig, Austin
American-Statesman) (l, a) MOVED.

   NEWS FOR KIDS

   NFK-CHECKITOUT _ A brief on a new web site, TV show or event for
kids. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   NFK-NEWSFLASH _ Three or four briefs of world and national news,
written for kids to understand. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED.

   NFK-FEATURE-ANIMALS _ A feature about a celebrity kid, kid's
event, or big news story explained for kids, for papers' kids or
family pages. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   MOVIES-HANKGREENBERG _ A swing and a hit! A new documentary
about the life of baseball legend Hank Greenberg, the first
big-league Jewish superstar, is becoming a sleeper sensation _ a
movie that's generating strong interest from baseball fans and
Jewish-Americans alike. (Passy, Palm Beach Post). 34.

   HOLLOWAY-TVCOLUMN _ Observations on the television industry from
a leading commentator. This week: UPN. (Holloway, Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   NEWSSTAND _ Periodicals on the newsstands this week. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   BOOKS-BALLPARK _ A look at 'The Ballpark Book.' Weekly books
column by Scott Eyman (Eyman, PlBOOKS)

   BOOKS-FORK _ Review of two books, ``FORK IN THE ROAD,'' by Denis
Hamill and ``RUN,'' by Douglas E. Winter. One is a good read,
forget the other. (Reid, Palm Beach Post)

   BOOKS-MILES _ Review of the book ``Miles and Me,'' by Quincy
Troupe. 'Miles and Me' is,a lesser book than Troupe's previous
outing, but it's an indispensible and entertaining look at the
musical giant in his more mundane moments. Just remember to duck
whenever the big man speaks. (Neal, Palm beach Post). 17.

   SCIENCE-MEDICINE

   SPAS _ People go to health spas to relax, but also to learn
healthier eating patterns or to jump-start a weight loss or fitness
program. They do great when they're there, but the real work comes
in the weeks and months after they return home. We'll talk to some
who've succeeded, and some who've failed, and find out what worked
and didn't. (Hamilton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).. 25. WITH
PHOTOS

   DIABETES _ Type 2 diabetes has historically been a disease of
adults. But new research shows it is growing dramatically among
children - often because of inactivity and poor diet. With a new
CDC report sounding the alarm on the rise in diabetes nationally,
we offer a consumer's guide to parents on how to keep kits healthy
and fit, to reduce their risk of diabetes. (Lore, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 18.

   PARALYSIS-REHAB _ Even though she is paralyzed below her neck
and breathes through a tube, Pat Bodie works for a living. She can
type and dial the telephone through her computer, moving and aiming
a radio signal on her forehead. She can operate her television and
stereo from her wheelchair or bed, flicking a special switch with
the slight movement she can control in one wrist.''Without the
technology I have, I would not be as independent.'' Access to that
technoloyy is in jeopardy with the liquidation of Franciscan
Medical Center, where Bodie was retrofitted for daily life in the
Franciscan Rehabilitation Center's nationally recognized assisstive
technology services component. (Dayton Daily News). 47. WITH PHOTO.

   SPORTS

   SPORTS-WEB _ Atlanta Journal-Constitution Staff Writer Al Levine
spends the weekend ``watching'' sports events on the internet and
tells the tale. (Levine, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 22.

   BASEBALL

   GREENBERG _ A swing and a hit! A new documentary about the life
of baseball legend Hank Greenberg, the first big-league Jewish
superstar, is becoming a sleeper sensation _ a movie that's
generating strong interest from baseball fans and Jewish-Americans
alike. With art. (Passy, Palm Beach Post)

   FOOTBALL/COLLEGES

   FBC-QUINCYCARTER _ A fresh look at Ga. quarterback Quincy Carter
as the Bulldogs begin final prep for opener against Georgia
Southern on Saturday. (Schlabach, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
25.

   FBC-DUKE _ DURHAM, N.C. _ Coverage of Duke football weekly media
conference. (Greenville Daily Reflector).

   FBC-NCSTATE _ RALEIGH, N.C. _ Coverage of N.C. State football
weekly media conference. (Greenville Daily Reflector).

   FBC-BEST _ Olin Buchanan lists the all-time best schools by
position. For example, Ohio State rates as the best school for wide
receivers. (Buchanan, Austin American-Statesman). 20.

   FOOTBALL/PROS

   COWBOYS _ The Dallas Cowboys' roster is set for the 2000 NFL
season. (Cantu, Austin American-Statesman).

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EDT and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

   Night news editor Todd C. Duncan, 404-526-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay, 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves at 10 a.m., 2 p.m. and 6 p.m. EDT and
afterwards as necessary based on news developments. If stories will
move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be given. All times are Eastern
unless otherwise noted.

   HOW TO REACH US

   Questions should be directed to CoxNet, the Cox News Service, in
Atlanta at 800-950-3739 or 404-526-5456. We are staffed 8 a.m. to
10 p.m. Monday-Friday, and 1-10 p.m. on weekends and holidays.

   News editor Tom Oder, 404-526-5887, toder(at)coxnews.com.

   Night news editor Todd C. Duncan, 404-526-7282,
tduncan(at)coxnews.com

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com
